title: Incredible moment a golden eagle battles a fox over a carcass
title_page: Incredible moment a golden eagle battles a fox over a carcass | Daily Mail Online
text:
A brave fox and a golden eagle battled it out for some food in a remote part of Scotland - and the incredible encounter was captured on camera.
The predators were filmed fighting for survival in the snow-capped Loch Lomond and Trossachs National Park, an area of mountains and glens in the middle of the country.
The rare footage shows the eagle pecking at the carcass of a deer when the hungry and opportunist fox approaches.
The eagle is filmed pecking at the carcass of a deer when the hungry and opportunist fox approaches
The fox bares its teeth as it moves towards the bird of prey in a bid to scare it away from the limited food
At first you would expect a bird to simply fly away but as this is a golden eagle - the second largest bird of prey in the UK after the white-tailed sea eagle - it stands its ground.
What follows is a fight between the two animals as the eagle tries to scare the fox away by brandishing its razor sharp talons.
The fox responds by baring its teeth in a bid to intimidate the bird as both intend to scare the other away from the limited food supply.
The video, which was captured by a team from the BBC, was broadcast on Winterwatch.
The team spent two years trying to capture footage of a golden eagle feasting on a deer carcass after laying bait at the site.
The golden eagle - the second largest bird of prey in the UK after the white-tailed sea eagle - stands its ground
The eagle tries to scare the fox away by brandishing its razor sharp talons as its rival fights back by biting
But they got a little more than what they bargained for when they filmed this exchange.
Presenter Chris Packham explained the footage was the kind of thing that even the most ardent eagle watcher would be fortunate to see in a lifetime.
He noted that it was incredible to see two apex predators risking potentially life-threatening injuries in order to feast on the deer carcass.
He described the video as 'amazing, exciting and fascinating,' adding that it was 'undoubtedly the most exciting' thing he had ever seen on the Watches.
